name: Yangon
fun_fact: Fun fact: Mohinga, Myanmar's national dish, is sold from street carts at dawn by vendors who've been making the same fish broth recipe for generationsâ€”some families guard their spice blend like a state secret, and locals can taste the difference between neighborhoods.

hero_dishes.name: Mohinga at Myaung Mya Daw Cho
hero_dishes.description: Rice noodles in rich, pungent fish broth with lemongrass, ginger, and crispy frittersâ€”Myanmar's breakfast obsession
hero_dishes.origin_story: Myaung Mya Daw Cho is known citywide for having the thickest, most ginger-forward mohinga broth. Street vendors sell it everywhere, but this restaurant's version is considered the gold standard. The broth simmers for hours
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Myaung Mya Daw Cho (famous for thick, bright broth), U Lay Gyi Mohingha (local breakfast stalls throughout Yangon)

hero_dishes.name: Lahpet Thoke (Tea Leaf Salad) at Rangoon Tea House
hero_dishes.description: Fermented tea leaves mixed with roasted peanuts, sesame seeds, fried garlic, dried shrimp, and tomatoesâ€”sour, crunchy, bitter, and completely unique
hero_dishes.origin_story: Myanmar is the only country that eats tea leaves as food. Rangoon Tea House serves the best version in Yangon: the pickled tea is slightly bitter and earthy, mixed with crispy elements. It's addictive once you acquire the taste
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Rangoon Tea House (Ground Floor, 77-79 Pansodan Street), Kaung Lay TeaLeaf Salad Shop, or Feel Myanmar Food

hero_dishes.name: Shan Noodles at 999 Shan Noodle House
hero_dishes.description: Rice noodles in savory broth or tossed dry with chicken, peanuts, and sesame oilâ€”Shan cuisine's greatest export to Yangon
hero_dishes.origin_story: 999 Shan Noodle House has served food inspired by Shan State since 1978. Shan noodles differ from Burmese: lighter broth, rice noodles, and optional chili oil. This is Yangon's most famous Shan restaurant
hero_dishes.where_to_find: 999 Shan Noodle House (since 1978â€”most searched restaurant in Myanmar), Aung Mingalar (behind Bogyoke Market)

hero_dishes.name: Traditional Curry at Aung Thukha
hero_dishes.description: Burmese curries with your choice of meat (chicken, pork, fish) served with rice and a dozen small side dishesâ€”oil-rich and deeply flavored
hero_dishes.origin_story: Aung Thukha in Bahan suburb is where locals go for authentic home-style curries. All dishes are pre-cooked and displayed in traysâ€”you point at what you want. The Burmese curry style uses more oil than Thai or Indian versions
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Aung Thukha (Bahan suburbâ€”hidden local favorite), Feel Myanmar Food (chain with more touristy atmosphere)

signature_drinks.name: Burmese Tea (Lahpet Yay)
signature_drinks.description: Strong, sweet milky tea served hot or icedâ€”the social lubricant of Myanmar
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Tea shops are Yangon's living rooms. Locals sip tea for hours while discussing politics, business, and gossip. It's served with condensed milk, very sweet, and always comes with free water

signature_drinks.name: Sugarcane Juice
signature_drinks.description: Fresh-pressed sugarcane juice served ice-cold with a squeeze of limeâ€”sweet, grassy, refreshing
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Sold from street carts where vendors crank sugarcane through a press. It's the perfect antidote to Yangon's tropical heat and spicy food

food_culture_notes: Mohinga for breakfast is non-negotiableâ€”locals eat it before work from street carts that appear at dawn
Tea leaf salad (lahpet thoke) is the only cuisine in the world that eats fermented tea leaves, not just drinks tea
Burmese curry is oil-heavy compared to Thai or Indianâ€”the oil preserves the curry in tropical heat
Tea shops are Myanmar's social hubs where people spend hours debating over sweet milky tea
